title: Will legislation eliminating the unit limit per manufacturer for the U.S. federal electric vehicle tax credit become law before 1 January 2020?
preds: Not going to happen this year.
The Congressional spending package was the last opportunity for this and no extension of the current limits or elimination thereof was agreed. Reportedly, the WH fought back against it, per Axios.
Will legislation eliminating the unit limit per manufacturer for the U.S. federal electric vehicle tax credit become law before 1 January 2020?  I like round numbers.

Between 4% and 10% of bills become laws depending on which source you use. [3,4] There are two bills in the 116 Congress: 
* H.R. 2256: Driving America Forward Act
* S. 1094: Driving America Forward Act According to Skopol Labs, which uses machine learning to tell the probability of passage purely based on the text of the bill, they have a 2% and 4% chance of enactment respectively. [1] Both seek to increase, not eliminate the limit. Bills that sought to eliminate the limit were unsuccessful in the last Congress. [2]  Furthermore, there has been no progress since April. Further furthermore, the Trump administration has indicated opposition to the subsidies before making it less likely he’d sign a bill to that effect [2]. The IRS code was enacted in 2008 and stipulated the phased-out elimination of the tax credit based on manufacturer production.  Since then states enacted additional incentives for the propping up of the electric vehicle market and jump start the alternative fuel vehicle economy.  The side effect of this was lower revenue to the states via gasoline taxes which were not collected by an increasing all-electric vehicle fleet on the streets.  Illinois and other states are considering huge increases in the annual registration fees for electric vehicles to augment the lost revenue from uncollected gasoline taxes.  Trump has already announced he does not support extending the tax credits from the 2008 act beyond the existing parameters.  Though legislation has been proposed to extend this tax incentive, it seems to be more of a election-cycle parlor game without much broad political appeal with legislatures and not much mainstream media attention.  It appears this legislation has an uphill battle.  On the other hand, pushing for tax incentives has broad public appeal and may be the political trick needed for many of the incumbent candidates need for their re-election cycle.

By “eliminating” does the question mean “eliminating the current limit” (i.e. raising the limit would count as a “yes”) or removing the limit altogether (i.e. raising the limit would not count as a “yes”)? Reducing on the chance it’s the latter.

The crowd puts the chances at 10%.  It does look like a longshot, especially given the current administration's hostility towards anything that reduces greenhouse gases.  If the crowd is right, and I keep the chances at 3%, I'll get (0-0.03)^2 + (1-0.97)^2 +  = 0.0018 Brier points.  The average forecaster will get (1-0.9)^2 + (0-0.1)^2 = 0.02.  I'll only beat the average by 0.0182 Brier points.  So there isn't much downside for betting on the longshot having a slightly greater probability, but keeping the odds still fairly slim. If I bet that it won't happen, but put the odds at 13%, and it doesn't happen, the score is calculated as follows:  Brier points = (0-0.13)^2 + (1-0.87)^2 +  = 0.0338 Brier points.  That will lag the average forecaster by only 0.0338 - 0.02 = 0.0138.  But if something happens later this year, and congress passes a bill that the President signs, we'll all be wrong.  The average forecaster will receive (1-0.1)^2 + (0-0.9)^2 = 1.62 Brier points.  And I'll get (1-0.13)^2 + (0-0.87)^2 = 1.514 Brier points.  The risk of going slightly higher than the crowd (13%) is 0.0138 Brier points.  And the potential reward is 1.62-1.514 = 0.106 Brier points.  The ratio of the reward to the risk is about 7.7. I've convinced myself that I've been approaching this forecasting thing all wrong.  At times I've gone with the consensus, but gone with a more extreme forecast.  From now on I'll hedge my bets more.  The other lesson is that to significantly beat the average forecaster you have to be right on something that the crowd is not seeing correctly.  That can be a hard thing to do.

Unfortunately, the phrasing is ambiguous regarding an increase/extension of the unit cap. I will interpret "eliminating the unit limit per manufacturer" to mean that an increase of the limit is not an elimination of the limit. This also makes sense given that past bills only proposed an elimination (see below), not an increase. Base rate for any introduced bill to pass is only 4%. [7] I'd assume it's even lower for partisan bills (unless they control both chambers of Congress). Several bills in this space have been proposed from what I can tell.
- Last July an elimination of the *unit* cap was proposed "Electric CARS Act". [1] This was not a bipartisan effort and the source deems the bills "too ambitious". The same (?) bill was also introduced in the Senate (?) in September. [2] Again, a democratic, not bipartisan effort. It will probably be reintroduced this year. [3] Rep. Khanna has now proposed a similar bill, pushing for the elimination of the *unit* cap. [4]
- In April 2019, a "bipartisan group of U.S. lawmakers introduced legislation on Wednesday to expand the electric vehicle tax credit by 400,000 vehicles per manufacturer. [...] The bill is sponsored by Democratic Senators Debbie Stabenow and Gary Peters, Republican Senators Lamar Alexander and Susan Collins and Democratic Representative Dan Kildee. [...] GM and Tesla shares rose on Reuters report that the bill would be introduced. Tesla shares recently traded up nearly 1 percent, while GM was up 0.2 percent. [...] The bill dubbed the “Driving America Forward Act” would grant each automaker a $7,000 tax credit for an additional 400,000 vehicles on top of the existing 200,000 vehicles eligible for $7,500 tax credits. [...] The proposal has strong backing from automakers, environmental groups and others, but will face opposition. Last month, the White House proposed immediately eliminating the $7,500 tax credit, a move it said would save the U.S. government $2.5 billion over a decade. Senator John Barrasso, a Republican who chairs the Environment and Public Works Committee, in February proposed legislation to end the credit and impose a highway user fee on EVs to pay for road repairs. The bill is backed by major automakers including GM, Tesla, Toyota Motor Corp, Ford Motor Co, Fiat Chrysler Automobiles NV, Honda Motor Co, BMW AG, Nissan Motor Co, Volkswagen AG and utilities." [5] I assign much more probability to the latter bill being passed (a unit *extension*, not elimination). It has bipartisan support and the explicit backing of the relevant industry groups (although I'd assume they'd also support the elimination bill). Any opposition to it will also work against the elimination bill. The elimination bill already failed to pass lat year. I also looked at the legislative effectiveness ratings of the people involved (those I could find) [6]:  ELIMINATION:
- Heinrich: 0.649
- Merkley: 0.993
- Masto: 0.150
- Rosen: 0.472
- couldn't find Walsh
- AVERAGE: 0.556 ELIMINATION:
- Khanna: 1.421 
- AVERAGE: 1.421 UNIT EXTENSION:
- Stabenow:  0.551
- Peters: 1.634
- Alexander: 1.364
- Collins: 1.756
- Kildee: 0.224
- AVERAGE: 1.1058 This also gives a 2x edge to the unit extension bill (ignoring Khanna for now since it's only been planned). Overall, I'd give about a 2% chance of unit elimination passing. [1] https://electrek.co/2018/07/02/new-bill-electric-car-federal-tax-credit-tesla-limit/

[5] https://www.reuters.com/article/us-autos-electric-taxcredit-exclusive/exclusive-u-s-lawmakers-introduce-bill-to-boost-electric-car-tax-credits-idUSKCN1RM1NG
[6] https://thelawmakers.org/find-representatives#/

Two new bills, one in the House and one in the Senate, propose to repeal the credits altogether: https://www.autonews.com/retail/senate-house-bills-aim-kill-7500-ev-tax-credit The tax credits have well-organized and well-funded opponents: The American Petroleum Institute is lobbying against the tax credits. https://www.api.org/news-policy-and-issues/news/2019/02/06/legislation-ending-ev-tax-credits-saves-taxpayers-billions-and-strengthens-infra The Koch brothers have reportedly done so in the past. The Democrats in the House are currently focusing on the Green New Deal, an expansive program for government spending on climate and equity. That may steal too much attention away from individual issues like the EV tax credits. On the other hand, it could galvanize support for anything climate related. Still, I see no signs that the Democrats are aiming to extend the limits.
Eleven months to go, not all of them equally risky.

Lowering further. There are a number of possible scenarios where lawmakers extend credits somehow wihtout eliminating the unit limits. For example, lawmakers may simply increase the unit limits. After all, lawmakers do not want to commit to limitless subsidies. Such measures gain the support of detractors by including provisions that cap their overall costs. Unit limits are one way to do that (another might be to have a sunset clause in the form of: past year X, the credits are phased out gradually). Lawmakers may also sign a brand new law for incentivizing EVs.
Hard to say. I'm going to go with slightly less likely.

The tax credits date from the first two years of Obama's first term when Democrats controlled the Presidency, the House and the Senate. [1]. The tax credits are on the one hand popular with climate hawk democrats. At the same time, they draw ire from lawmakers who just see them as a way to allow rich people to buy cool cars. That's not a totally inaccurate view of the tax credits as their short term effect is indeed to make expensive cars slightly cheaper for those who can afford to buy a 50k+ car. Their long term effect is in fact to bring EV technology down its learning curve and usher an era of affordable EVs. But lawmakers may ignore long-term considerations in favor of more pressing issues for their constituents. There is high profile opposition against the credits. Trump administration has planned to end the tax credit. [2] Senator Barrosso (R), Senate Environment and Public Works Chairmam, has introduced legislation to end them [3]. On the other hand, some senators/representatives on both sides of the isle have introduced bills to extend them [3]. An extension is a possibility if Democrats are willing to push hard enough for one in exchange for compromise on other matters.  A potential reference class: tax credits for wind turbines were removed and reinstated several times in the last few decades. But wind turbines provide cheap power to communities across America and draw support across the political spectrum. Not sure EVs are quite in the same category, yet.  [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Government_incentives_for_plug-in_electric_vehicles#Federal_government
[2] https://electrek.co/2018/12/03/trump-end-electric-car-tax-credit/
[3] https://www.forbes.com/sites/jimgorzelany/2018/11/13/will-the-next-congress-extend-or-kill-the-electric-car-tax-credit/#2d5ee2d24e42
